div.head: The AUTHOR TO HIS FRIEND.
div.p:
YO∆≤ ≈øee here, my highly-e≈øteemed Friend, part of a certain Excellent Writing, dige≈øted into brief Aphori≈øms, as a Compendium of all tho≈øe things which Phylo≈øophers are wont to ob≈øerve, about the great Work of their Stone: Not that all things are here expounded which belong to the Compleat De≈øcription of the Phy≈øical Tincture; for there are more things yet behind, with which the Author intends to adorn it; ina≈ømuch as he hath determined to fortifie the≈øe Aphori≈øms which he hath here emitted, from the Authority of the Principal Phylo≈øophers: in which Work he will accurately explain the Similitudes, Figures, and other ob≈øcure and confu≈øed manners of ≈øpeaking, which every where occur in the Writings of Phylo≈øophers. That ≈øo at length tho≈øe things which hitherto have been delivered
too intricately, and confu≈øedly by mo≈øt Writers, may appear in ≈øome Methodical Order. Neverthele≈øs, the principal ≈øcope of this Author, is not ≈øo much to expo≈øe or ≈øet forth his own Inventions, as to reduce the valuable Sayings of others into order; which he willingly ≈øubmitteth to the Judgment and Examination of tho≈øe, who have made a greater Progre≈øs in the Art than him≈øelf.

But although I know this to be the purpo≈øe of the Learned Author, neverthele≈øs I chu≈øe rather to tran≈ømit this little work to you, imperfect as it is, that you may weigh it, and cau≈øe it to be printed, then that the Sons of Art ≈øhould any longer want this ≈ømall help; that it may give a light to tho≈øe who err and go a≈øtray in the mid≈øt of darkne≈øs.
